title.narrative: Sustainable Food and Nutrition Security in Red Sea State (SFNS-RSS)
Sustainable Food and Nutrition Security in Red Sea State (SFNS-RSS)

description.narrative: The project Sustainable Food and Nutrition Security in Red Sea State (SFNS-RSS) uses an integrated approach1 to address food and nutrition insecurity caused by challenging conditions for farming, a degraded natural environment, lack of income opportunities and a weak social and physical infrastructure including insufficient hygiene and nutrition practices. The SFNS-RSS project promotes sustainable Natural Resource Management (NRM) for climate and disaster resilience, resulting in restored and productive land assets for smallholder agropastoral families in vulnerable rural communities in the semi-arid desert areas of Red Sea State (RSS). All interventions related to land use and natural resources will be based on a Participatory Land Use Plan (PLP) and Environmental and Social Impact Assessment (ESIA) carried out at the initial phase of the project. Building up agricultural resources, community infrastructure and nutrition knowledge, SFNSRSS will increase productivity and improve dietary diversity and nutrition practices among the most vulnerable population groups. Trainings and the rehabilitation or establishment of Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) infrastructure are the second tier of SFNS-RSS and will result in better access to water and improved hygiene practices. To support Womens Economic Empowerment, WHH and its partner Abuhadia Society for Women and Community Development (ASWCD) will implement Income Generating Activities (IGAs) following the recommendations of a Gender and Market Analysis. Covid19 components form part of the project to promote awareness and resources for infection prevention and control alongside the regular hygiene promotion.

Welthungerhilfe har lagt fram ett projektförslag som heter Sustainable Food and Nutrition Security in Red Sea State (SFNS-RSS). Detta är ett treårigt projekt på 49 800 000 SEK som syftar till att ta itu med de viktigaste sårbarheterna för målgrupperna, främst småbrukare av jordbrukspastoralister i (RSS). Den direkta målgruppen är 12 500 hushåll med cirka 62 500 individer.
Det övergripande målet för SFNS-RSS-projektet är att småbrukare inom jordbrukspastoral i Agig, Haya, Dordeib, Tokar och Sinkat ska ha en hållbart förbättrad livsmedels- och näringssäkerhet.
Följande 2 resultat kommer att bidra till dess uppnåendet: 1) Förbättrad jordbruksproduktivitet, klimatresistens och mat- och näringssäkerhet 2) Förbättrad säker vattenförsörjning och hygienpraxis
SFNS-RSS använder ett integrerat tillvägagångssätt för att ta itu med livsmedels- och näringssäkerhet orsakad av utmanande förhållanden för jordbruk, en försämrad naturlig miljö, brist på inkomstmöjligheter och en svag social och fysisk infrastruktur, inklusive otillräcklig hygien och näringspraxis.
SFNS-RSS-projektet kommer att främja hållbar förvaltning av naturresurser (NRM) för klimat- och katastrofbeständighet, vilket resulterar i återställda och produktiva marktillgångar för småbrukare i jordbruksfamiljer i utsatta landsbygdssamhällen i de halvtorra ökenområdena i RSS. Genom att bygga upp jordbruksresurser, samhällsinfrastruktur och kunskap om näring kommer SFNS-RSS att öka produktiviteten och förbättra kostmångfald och näringspraxis bland de mest utsatta befolkningsgrupperna.
Utbildningar och rehabilitering eller etablering av infrastruktur för vatten, sanitet och hygien (WASH) är den andra delen av SFNS-RSS och kommer att resultera i bättre tillgång till vatten och förbättrad hygienpraxis. En Covid -19 komponent ingår i projektet för att främja medvetenhet och resurser för infektionsförebyggande och -kontroll vid sidan av den vanliga hygienfrämjandet.
Insatsens totala budget är 49 800 000 SEK

Welthungerhilfe has submitted a project proposal called Sustainable Food and Nutrition Security in Red Sea State (SFNS-RSS). This is a three year, 49 800 000 SEK project aimed at adressing the key vulnerabilities of the target groups, mainly smallholder agro-pastoralists in RSS.The direct target group is 12 500 households with approximetly 62 500 individuals.
The overall objective of the SFNS-RSS project is for smallholder agro-pastoralist households in Agig, Haya, Dordeib, Tokar and Sinkat to have sustainably improved Food and Nutrition Security.
The following 2 outcomes (results) will contribute to its achievement: 1) Improved agricultural productivity, climate resilience and food and nutrition security 2) Improved safe water supply and hygiene practices
SFNS-RSS uses an integrated approach to address food and nutrition insecurity caused by challenging conditions for farming, a degraded natural environment, lack of income opportunities and a weak social and physical infrastructure including insufficient hygiene and nutrition practices.
The SFNS-RSS project objective is to sustainable natural resource management (NRM) for climate and disaster resilience, resulting in restored and productive land assets for smallholder agro-pastoral families in vulnerable rural communities in the semi-arid desert areas of RSS. Building up agricultural resources, community infrastructure and nutrition knowledge, SFNS-RSS will increase productivity and improve dietary diversity and nutrition practices among the most vulnerable population groups.
Trainings and the rehabilitation or establishment of Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) infrastructure are the second tier of SFNS-RSS and will result in better access to water and improved hygiene practices. A Covid -19 component forms part of the project to promote awareness and resources for infection prevention and control alongside the regular hygiene promotion.
The budget is set at 49 800 000 SEK

tag.narrative: 15.3 - By 2030, combat desertification, restore degraded land and soil, including land affected by desertification, drought and floods, and strive to achieve a land degradation-neutral world.

15.3 - Till 2030 bekämpa ökenspridning, återställa förstörd mark och jord, inklusive mark som drabbats av ökenspridning, torka och översvämningar, samt sträva efter att uppnå en värld utan nettoförstöring av mark.
2.1 - By 2030, end hunger and ensure access by all people, in particular the poor and people in vulnerable situations, including infants, to safe, nutritious and sufficient food all year round.

2.1 - Senast 2030 avskaffa hunger och garantera alla människor, i synnerhet de fattiga och människor i utsatta situationer, inklusive små barn, tillgång till tillräckligt med säker och näringsrik mat året om.

2.4 - By 2030, ensure sustainable food production systems and implement resilient agricultural practices that increase productivity and production, that help maintain ecosystems, that strengthen capacity for adaptation to climate change, extreme weather, drought, flooding and other disasters and that progressively improve land and soil quality.

2.4 - Senast 2030 uppnå hållbara system för livsmedelsproduktion samt införa motståndskraftiga jordbruksmetoder som ökar produktiviteten och produktionen, som bidrar till att upprätthålla ekosystemen, som stärker förmågan till anpassning till klimatförändringar, extrema väderförhållanden, torka, översvämning och andra katastrofer och som successivt förbättrar mark- och jordkvaliteten.

Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative:
ACTIVITIES PLANNED FOR THE REPORTING PERIOD The year 2021 (first 4 months of the project) was dedicated mainly to the signing of the Technical Agreement (TA) with MoPER and Humanitarian Aid Commission (HAC) on Red Sea State and Federal levels; and signing MoUs with WES, assessing the local implementing partner; and carrying out baseline and other studies to guide the project implementation. The Gender and Market study was conducted by the local partner organization ASWCD, as they are specialising in women empowerment and income generation.
1. Preparatory Phase Staff recruitment: WHH recruited staff required for the project implementation. Specified as follows: Logistician, Nutrition Officer, WASH Officer, HR Officer and one extra Guard and Driver Assets: WHH procured 2 vehicles required for the project. Kick off Workshop: This was organised in December 2021 after the technical agreement was signed with HAC. The main purpose of the workshop was to inform different stakeholders (community leaders, locality authorities, technical staff from line ministries) of all the targeted communities about the project strategy and implementation plan. No media were involved. Dordieb and Hayat are new areas for WHH, and the presence was warmly welcomed by these communities. Baseline study: The TOR prepared in October2021 and later shared with Sida for their endorsement. Then WHH announced a simple competitive procurement in November, but WHH were not satisfied with all applied consultancy offices, Again WHH re-announced in 17the of December but unfortunately only 2 offers were received but the cost was for both offers here than the allocated budget. And finally, WHH decided to contract iSPR group of consultancies in January 2022 after informed SIDA with the overbudget Balance needed to be paid. PLP and ESIA: The TR also prepared in October 2021 and the consultancy was announced in November. In in the first round no one applied, we it was readvertised. Finally Nubian Stone applied and was contracted in the beginning of January 2022. Mesquite Value chain study: The ToR was prepared in November 2021. WHH is still tendering to identify a consultant with suitable experience and capacity to conduct the study. Worsening food crisis looming in Sudan amid economic downturn, displacement, and ruined crops.
2. Implementation Phase The following activities were planned to be carried out or to start during the reporting period. Outcome 1: Improved agricultural productivity, climate resilience and food and nutrition security
Very few activities were planned for the reporting period, but preparations for assessments and studies were made. Before any activities are implemented, Technical Agreement and MoUs signed with line ministry and endorsed by HAC had to be in place. This only took place in November. This delayed the initiation of project implementation.
Output 1.1: Agriculturally productive land increased, and agricultural production improved through agroecological practices A1.1.1 Organize communities for Participatory Land Use Planning (PLP) and ESIA Finding a suitable consultant for acceptable price took time, and the field work for the consultancy started in February 2022. A Sudanese environmental consulting company, Nubian Stone, was selected because they are the only entity in the country with experience of this method. The field work was prepared by invitation of the officials for kick off meeting in port Sudan (MoPER, WES, NFC, Soil Conservation & Range Land Departments, and targeted Localities executive managers) and the same time the targeted communities mobilization take place through community meetings 2021 Annual Report: SFNS-RSS 4 and meetings with local leaders. During the PLP, information was gathered through different methods, varying from FGDs to taking soil and water samples and aerial pictures.
A1.1.3 Mesquite Management Initiative One of the project objectives is to create economically viable opportunitiesto manage mesquite, which as an invasive species is harmful for agriculture and cattle. ToR for a consultancy on mesquite value chain was prepared in 2021 and published early 2022. Currently WHH has identified a consultant with local knowledge and previous experience in mesquite market value chains. This activity can be concluded by Q2-3, which will allow the project to proceed with alternative mesquite uses, if applicable.
A 1.1.4 Organize 25 Farmer Field Schools (FFS) It was not possible to start the activity as planned in December 2021, because the TA with HAC was pending, as well as the baseline study. This resulted in the farming season being missed in the areas of Agig and Tokar that receive winter rain, which will be partly compensated by extending activities in 2022 in localities where weather conditions allow, and the project is likely to reach the planned number of farmers. (3 months added April-May and August)
Output 1.2: Households have improved knowledge and access to practice good nutrition A1.2.3 Training on horticulture production in demonstration gardens The activity was moved same as 1.1.4., it will start in April 2022 [has started as planned as of 18/04/2022].
Output 1.3: At the end of the projects targeted household are able to earn a regular cash income from the livelihood activities supported by the project
Summary Gender Market and Best Practice Assessment Abuhadia Society for Women and Community Development (ASWCD) has conducted a Gender market and best practice assessment in five target localities, to mainstream gender considerations into the project activities. The study aims to shed a light on gender roles, access to and control of resources as well as external factors that have an impact on gender relations. The study found that while men are the primary earners and are predominantly the decision makers in households and control access to money and make decisions on spending, there is also important space for women. For example, women hold power over self-generated income, such as from production and sale of handicrafts. In general, men always control expenditure. Respondents of the study have pointed towards women being consulted in HH decision making, whereas leadership and decision-making roles on community level are dominated by men. Women are considered by half the respondents, only to be able to lead in womens affairs. There is still a traditional division of work, and outside of unpaid domestic work, women can mainly be found taking care of small ruminants. In addition, more than half of the respondents reported that women cannot travel without a companion, and one-third agrees that it should only be with the permission of a husband or parents. Only about 15% of women stated they had free movement.
The other main constraints women face in order to gain physical access to markets are: distance from household to the marketplace; traditions preventing women from selling in market; and lack of separate market for women to market their products.
Their reported prioritized income generating activities would be handicrafts, petty trade, food processing, selling of improved stoves, agriculture & horticulture, raising of small animals (goats and sheep), perfume making, poultry keeping, milk productions and/or sewing and tailoring
Based on these findings, ADWCD has made recommendations for successful gender responsive project implementation: 2021 Annual Report: SFNS-RSS
1) The project should adopt a gender strategy that will improve womens position and bargaining power, based on a cooperative and not a confrontational approach; 2) Conduct a training needs assessment in each locality prior to starting training for women; 3) Encourage share of experience and learning among women groups in low cost and effective methods; 4) Introduce easily accessible financing method for women groups to access loans and funds that is transparent and highly accountable e.g., mobilize village saving and loan associations (VSLA); 5) Advocate and lobby with localities to identify separate market locations for women, so that they have power over what they sell and their respective income; 6) Provide a market information mechanism for women and assist them to adapt appropriate pricing strategies. 7) Intensify business management and marketing skills of (beginners) female entrepreneurs, to improve their chances of running a successful small business. 8) Adapt activities, mainly trainings, according to seasonality or products and their prices as well as availability e.g., food processing activities.
Output 1.4 Households have better knowledge and access to services and support for improved livelihood outcomes
A1.4.3 Civil society capacity development The local implementing partner ASWCD was selected among 3 candidates, mainly because of their profile as womens organization, and having already track record of implementing relevant projects and working with donors. The organizational capacity of ASWCD was done using a participatory assessment tool evaluating the organizations capacity in different areas of management, as well as in programming, networking, sectoral competence, etc. Weak points of the organization were identified for a capacity development plan. WHH will use an approach using in-house training and mentoring to strengthen the areas of M&E, HR and finance, and offer funding for additional training courses in areas like PCM and human rightsbased programming. The partnership agreement, including financial contribution, activities to be implemented by ASWCD, and capacity development plan, was signed in November/December 2021.
Outcome 2: Improved safe water supply and hygiene practices Most of the WASH components of the projects, especially the bigger hardware parts like building or rehabilitation of rainwater harvesting infrastructure, set-up or rehabilitation of hand pumps, and construction of latrines are planned for the dry seasons in 2022 and 2023. However, some preparatory initiatives were planned to happen already 2021, particularly the selection of water management committees, so that they had to be planned for February 2022 [preparatory initiatives have started in February 2022 as of April 2022].
Output 2.1: Committees functional and trained and linked to relevant state actors A 2.1.1 Set up Village Development Committees and Water Management Committees VDC members were selected in December 2021, but training activities will be started in 2022 after the Baseline Study is carried out. The selection of committee members was made considering the presentation of different livelihood groups, as well as participation of women. While the first step is to guarantee that women are part of the structure, making sure their meaningful participation and eventual leadership roles will be the next step. The identification of Water Committees was delayed because the WASH officer joined the RSS team only in January 2022
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
